Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Cosmological Expansion and Collapse via Loop Quantum Gravity and Superstring Theory

ProgramReference.Text: US CHINA COOP IN BASIC SCIENCE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The mysteries of the universe have been questioned and studied by every great civilization of the world and ours is no exception: how was it formed, how will it end, what governs its behavior, does it go on forever? Scientists who search for answers to these questions are known as cosmologists and astronomers (not to be confused with cosmetologists and astrologers).  There are a few ways this is done: observationally and theoretically. A famous tenet of relativity is that the speed of light is constant in vacuum and that nothing can travel faster than this. Since the universe is tremendously large, that means it can take billions of years for light to reach us from events far away. Thus, astronomers use telescopes to give us snapshots of various epochs in the changing universe. Theoretical cosmologists then try to fill in the blanks and make sense of this observational data to answer the big questions. As a theoretical cosmologist, I can tell you this is no easy task; the upside is there are now many satellite and ground-based experiments providing us with more phenomenological data than ever before. That is why it is so important that we have cosmologists working to extend our current models to predict what we will see and constrain the models that do not fit.

Specifically, I work in the area of quantum cosmology. In the simplest terms, quantum cosmology combines the two fields of quantum mechanics (which describes things on the smallest scales) and general relativity (which describes the effects of gravity). Both of these fields work exceedingly well in their respective regimes, but there is not yet an accepted theory that combines the two. One of the stronger candidates is loop quantum gravity, which has had great success in cosmology with models that resolve the big bang singularity. The singularity represents the breakdown of general relativity in this particular regime: the equations don’t work there because they do not include the quantum effects which become important when the universe is miniscule. This has given rise to bouncing models which predict that, rather than the universe collapsing to a singular point, the universe will collapse to a minimum non-zero volume and then rebound due to the quantum nature of space-time.

That was to be expected:  including quantum effects affects the small scale. However, Yongge Ma, a professor of physics in the Loop Quantum Gravity Group of Beijing Normal University had found some curious terms in the modified Friedmann equation given by his treatment. The Friedmann equation describes the expansion of the universe assuming isotropy and homogeneity, which are reasonable assumptions on large scales and often used in cosmology; modified refers to the quantum corrections. Depending on certain values, his research indicated that there could be quantum effects even at large scales! This was not expected and very intriguing, so I applied and received funding to collaborate with him in Beijing via the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) fellowship.  Professor Ma used a very particular method to arrive at these special terms, and so my research goal was to search for similar results, but with a more general approach, and then see how influential these terms might be at large scales.

Searching for specific terms in physics equations is actually quite similar to any every day search. First, you look in the most likely of places: for me, that was the factor ordering ambiguity. This ambiguity comes about because quantum equations depend on the order of operators, i.e. AB is not necessarily the same as BA. That didn’t work.
